Description: Landscape with Diana and Actaeon, record of a painting (whereabouts unknown) from the Liber Veritatis; naked figures bathing in a river which winds into the right foreground, a temple or tomb on a wooded hill at l Pen and brown ink and brown wash, heightened with white; on blue paper
Curator's comments: See 1957,1214.6 for information on the Liber Veritatis. According to the inscription, this drawing records a painting made by Claude in 1641 for a Mr Tardif that is now unknown. This is somewhat regrettable given that it is Claude’s only known depiction of this episode from Ovid. It is also one of two paintings that Claude made for this patron, who remains unknown, the other being the Flight into Egypt (for which see 1957,1214.66) which is also unknown. It appears however that both paintings were quite small and were presumably quite small. The handling is light, and spiritied, with the pink heightening lending a more painterly character to the drawing than a majority of the drawing in the Liber (for more on the Liber see 1957,1214.6). Lit: M. Roethlisberger, Claude Lorrain, The Paintings, London 1961, LV57, pp. 161–62; M. Roethlisberger, ‘Claude Lorrain. The Drawings’, Berkeley & Los Angeles, 1968, no. 466; M. Kitson, ‘Claude Lorrain: Liber Veritatis’, London 1978, no. 57.
Bibliographic references: Liber Veritatis 1978 / Claude Lorrain: Liber Veritatis (57)
